title: Comparison Operators (Comparing Values)
simplifierConcept:
How do you compare things in life?

C# has comparison operators:

== Equal to (is same?)
!= Not equal to (is different?)
> Greater than (is bigger?)
< Less than (is smaller?)
>= Greater or equal (at least?)
<= Less or equal (at most?)

All return TRUE or FALSE!

5 > 3  // true
10 == 10  // true
7 != 7  // false

Think: Comparison operators ask yes/no questions about values!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Double equals checks EQUALITY. Returns true if same, false if different. if (x == 5) checks if x is 5. NEVER use single = in if! That's assignment, not comparison!
Not equals checks DIFFERENCE. Exclamation mark means NOT. if (x != 5) is true when x is anything except 5. Opposite of ==.
> greater, < less, >= at least (or equal), <= at most (or equal). if (age >= 18) means 18 or older. >= and <= INCLUDE the number!
All comparisons return bool (true/false). Can store: bool result = (5 > 3); Can use directly in if: if (5 > 3) { ... } Always evaluates to boolean!

challenge.instructions:
Create a number guessing game!

1. Set a secret number (pick any number 1-100)
2. Ask user to guess
3. Compare guess to secret number:
   - If guess == secret: "Correct! You win!"
   - If guess > secret: "Too high! Try again."
   - If guess < secret: "Too low! Try again."
4. Also tell them how close they are:
   - If within 5: "You're very close!"
   - If within 10: "You're close!"
   - Otherwise: "You're far away!"

Example:
Secret number: 42
Guess: 50
Too high! Try again.
You're close! (50-42=8, within 10)

Guess: 42
Correct! You win!
challenge.hint: Use == to check exact match. > for too high. < for too low. Math.Abs(guess - secret) gives distance (always positive). Compare distance to 5 and 10.
commonStickingPoints: Using = instead of ==: if (x = 5) tries to ASSIGN 5 to x, not COMPARE! Always use == for comparison. Single = is assignment, double == is comparison!
Confusing >= and >: >= means greater OR equal. > means ONLY greater. if (age >= 18) includes 18. if (age > 18) starts at 19! Easy to mix up!
Comparing strings: "hi" == "Hi" is FALSE! C# is case-sensitive. Use .ToLower() to ignore case: if (text.ToLower() == "hi") matches "Hi", "HI", "hi".
Negative differences: guess - secret can be negative! 40 - 50 = -10. Use Math.Abs() to get absolute (positive) difference: Math.Abs(40 - 50) = 10.
